title: The Crusader: Age-old problem of vet’s bills
text:
The Crusader: Age-old problem of vet’s bills The Crusader: Age-old problem of vet’s bills A family’s pet insurance claim over a vet’s bill for their sick dog hit hurdle after hurdle until they shared their tale of woe with Crusader. PUBLISHED: 18:36, Sun, Aug 9, 2015 | UPDATED: 18:39, Sun, Aug 9, 2015 GETTY Treatment for pets is not cheap 
The Macks, mother Margaret and adult son Ian, faced deadlock after submitting £168 of charges for their sick dog Zeus to Animal Friends. 
“We have always paid the premiums and never claimed before but this is most unfair,” says Margaret, 73, from Surrey. 
The confusing demands and accusations of “misrepresentations” coming from Animal Friends did not help, they say. 
Zeus, a stray, became part of the Mack family five years ago after they adopted him from Battersea Dogs Home. 
Like all rescue dogs his age was approximate, as Ian, who is disabled, told Animal Friends when he took out cover in early 2011. 
He says: “I gave the policy details over the phone and the only thing the customer services person questioned was Zeus’s breed. 
He said he only had room for one type in the box but Zeus is a cross, so we settled on rottweiler. 
We gave his details exactly as we had received them.” 
No further questions were raised, Ian paid his premiums and Animal Friends accepted his money. In late spring this year, however, Zeus needed treatment. 
Although it was Ian’s policy, Margaret paid the vet’s bill. 
“My son was short of funds so I settled it,” she says. 
“I put down my bank account for repayment on the claim form, it tallied with the bill. 
Animal Friends rejected it saying this bank account number did not match the information they had. 
“We rang up several times explaining the reason. Ian and I have the same address and share the same surname, it seems obvious. 
“Then they queried the information about Zeus’s age, informing us that the age Ian had given over the phone was different to the one provided by the vet and that we must pay higher premiums and back payments.” 
The underwriter for Animal Friends is Red Sands, based in Gibraltar but regulated in the UK. 
After much to-ing and fro-ing, the insurer, which donates generously to animal charities, finally offered to refund the claim but wanted Ian to resubmit the forms first. 
This meant getting the vet to supply another bill. 
Yet after the policy’s £99 excess and other charges were taken off the family would only have been left with around £45 which, given the inconvenience they had endured, seemed rather mean. 
We suggested the insurer waive the excess as a goodwill gesture and pay Margaret. 
They agreed to do this. After asking several times for guidance about its payment policy and the reason for the problems in this case, late last week there was more clarity. Conflicting assessments of Zeus’s age raised questions. 
“Different premiums would be due for an older pet,” director of operations Natalie Surtees explained but stressed Animal Friends fully understood the issues with rescue dogs and that their ages were approximate. 
Anti-fraud concerns and the need to comply with regulations were the reason for questioning the payment. 
The Macks are delighted and hope that a letter they received from Animal Friends on Friday offering them just £45 is a mistake. 
Crusader will be monitoring the situation to ensure that all written promises are kept. Related articles
